content.text: The transition away from extractive industries, though challenging, offers significant opportunities for innovation and sustainable economic growth. However, this shift could lead to job displacement and economic shocks, necessitating strategies to support affected workers.

According to the International Labour Organization (ILO), efforts to limit global warming could create millions of new jobs globally, but the transition away from fossil fuels may also result in the loss of millions of jobs in the energy sector by 2030. Despite this, recent scenarios suggest that job creation will outpace losses. By 2030, 103 million new jobs could be created under sustainable energy and circular economy models. In 2022 alone, the global renewable energy sector added 1 million jobs, with solar photovoltaic (PV) leading this growth. Solar PV jobs reached 4.9 million, comprising over a third of the renewable energy workforce, with women holding 40% of these positions.

While this progress is encouraging, the transition must accelerate to address the estimated 78 million jobs at risk. The challenge lies in the limited overlap between fossil fuel and clean energy jobs, both geographically and in terms of job quality. This gap threatens to leave workers behind and could undermine political support for the energy transition.
To counter this, it is essential to leverage the entire clean energy value chain, such as localizing critical mineral supply chains and fostering downstream activities beyond extraction. This approach can create new jobs and build community support. However, a seamless transition from fossil fuel to clean energy roles is not always feasible. Therefore, supporting broader economic diversification, particularly in countries reliant on single industries, is crucial.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title:
PART 1 
Policy frameworks and reskilling initiatives

content.text:
Effective policy frameworks are key to facilitating the shift to green jobs, and capacity building efforts are necessary to upskill and reskill workers. The green jobs transition requires deliberate action to protect livelihoods and align education and training programs with emerging opportunities. For instance, Egypt’s Technical and Vocational Education and Training II project, a €116 million initiative, supports renewable energy programs across 13 institutions. Similarly, the Philippines’ Green Jobs Act encourages the creation, sustainability, and incentivization of green jobs, while improving workforce development planning.
In crisis settings, the just energy transition serves as an investment in long-term stability by fostering local capacities and infrastructure for recovery and development. Countries heavily dependent on energy imports, such as Yemen and Lebanon, demonstrate the potential of sustainable energy to build both resilience and livelihoods. Yemen’s ERRY III joint program, which focuses on upskilling over 1,100 individuals—particularly women—in solar services, and Lebanon’s training programs for women engineers are examples of how targeted initiatives can drive positive outcomes.

Just transition planning is critical to ensuring affected workers and communities are adequately supported throughout the process. By promoting inclusive and equitable economic diversification, policymakers can effectively manage the energy transition while advancing sustainable development and social equity.
Worker retraining and skills development programs are crucial in facilitating a smooth transition away from extractive industries. By providing workers with the necessary qualifications for sustainable roles in emerging sectors, these programs ensure that individuals can adapt to changing job markets and contribute to the growth of clean energy industries. 
Retraining and skills development programs are pivotal for a smooth transition away from extractive industries. By equipping workers with the qualifications needed for sustainable roles in emerging sectors, these programs help them adapt to changing job markets and contribute to the growth of clean energy industries. Many workers in traditional energy sectors already possess transferable skills. For example, oil and gas workers may transition to offshore wind or carbon capture projects, while coal miners could shift to mining critical minerals for low-carbon technologies.

Government assistance and targeted programs are crucial in helping unemployed workers find new opportunities, ensuring job quality, and promoting equitable benefit distribution. Addressing workplace safety, equity, and inclusion also fosters public acceptance of the energy transition.
Labor unions, industry associations, and educational institutions play a collaborative role in supporting retraining efforts. These partnerships facilitate access to training programs, advocate for worker rights, and promote industry-specific certifications, contributing to the effective implementation of just transition strategies.
The sustainable energy transition offers a chance to reduce inequalities in the sector. In Asia alone, an estimated 4.4 million additional engineers will be needed by 2030 to meet renewable energy targets. According to IRENA (2024), women currently make up only 15% of the wind sector workforce but 40% in solar PV in the region. Strengthening human capital to support the transition is an opportunity to increase women's participation in STEM and build a more inclusive workforce across Asia and the Pacific.

he transition to renewable energy necessitates comprehensive workforce development strategies to address the diverse challenges faced by workers from various sectors. While some skills from fossil fuel industries are transferable to clean energy roles, many workers will require targeted upskilling or reskilling to meet the specific demands of new positions. For example, transitioning from oil and gas to offshore wind may involve building upon existing competencies, but additional training is essential to ensure proficiency in the distinct aspects of renewable technologies (IEA, 2024)
A gender-sensitive approach is crucial to ensure an equitable transition. Expanding training opportunities for women, promoting their advancement into leadership roles within the energy sector, addressing risks of gender-based violence, and providing psychological support for all workers are critical components. Such measures not only foster inclusivity but also enhance the sector's capacity to meet evolving challenges by leveraging a diverse and skilled workforce.

content.title:
Case Study RBeC:
Bridging the Skills gap in North Macedonia

content.text: North Macedonia's unemployment rate in the second quarter of 2019 was 17.8%, higher than the EU average (6.2%) and the Western Balkans average (15.3%) over the same period[1].  Low labor force participation, especially among women and youth, coupled with a skills shortage, were major barriers to economic growth. Employers struggled to find qualified workers across key sectors, such as energy, textiles, and construction. EVN, an Austrian electricity company, urgently needed 500 electrical fitters, leaders in the textile sector were delaying the adoption of technology because of a shortage of qualified technicians, and the construction industry sought 600 technicians. Education needed to be prepared to meet the challenges of gasification and the renewable energy sector. Private sector employers were proposing to suspend foreign investment until the skills shortages were resolved. The shortage of skilled workers was therefore hampering job creation, productivity improvements and competitiveness in North Macedonia[2].

The "Bridging the Skills Gap to Create New and Better Jobs" project[3],[4] in Northern Macedonia therefore aimed to tackle unemployment and the "skills gap" in the textile, construction and renewable energy sectors through a variety of training models, including post-secondary education and non-formal training, such as regional vocational education and training centres (VET). [A1] The project targeted young people, the long-term unemployed and workers in need of better opportunities in the private sector. In collaboration with the Ministry of Education and Science, the strategy for achieving this objective was to map stakeholders, assess skills and create models and policies for vocational education and training (VET) centres. It helped companies understand labour market dynamics and identify the best approaches to skills development, whether through existing vocational schools or private sector facilities.

A multi-stakeholder platform brought together businesses, policymakers, and development practitioners to collaboratively assess labour market requirements and address the challenges faced by the textile, construction, and renewable energy sectors. By facilitating open dialogue between these key stakeholders, the platform enabled a comprehensive understanding of current and future skills demands, helping to identify critical skills gaps. This platform allowed a shared understanding of current and future skills needs and tested training models tailored to industry demands. 
Through sector-specific skills assessments and stakeholder mapping, the project was able to evaluate the best approaches for matching skills to industry needs. By addressing critical skills gaps and aligning adult learning programs with labour market demands, the project helped workers improve their qualifications and transition into higher-quality jobs. Moreover, the project emphasized the importance of adult learning programs, aligning them with labour demand to help workers improve their qualifications and move into higher-quality jobs.

The insights gained from this collaborative approach are expected to guide future educational policies, fostering a more dynamic and responsive vocational training system in North Macedonia. [A2] [A3]  
Lessons learned from the project have been used to update policies on post-secondary and vocational education reforms, considering legal obstacles and areas for improvement. The project focused on designing effective training in the textile, construction, and renewable energy sectors. [A4] It highlighted the need for formal education and skills-based training programs. Collaboration between government, educational institutions and industry was crucial, as was understanding current and future skills needs through labour market analysis. Engaging employers and addressing the mismatch between graduate skills and employer requirements were identified as key success factors. [A5] The adaptation of training programs to these variations was also explored.[A6]

By equipping workers, fostering inclusion, and empowering communities, this project paves the way for a sustainable and equitable shift towards renewable energy as the recommended route for a Just Energy Transition. The multi-sectoral approach employed by the project highlights the importance of collaboration in building a future powered by clean energy that benefits everyone.

References:
[1]https://www.etf.europa.eu/sites/default/files/document/Country%20Fiche%202020%20North%20Macedonia%20Education%20Training%20and%20Employment%20Developments.pdf
[2] https://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/sites/d786bb9d-en/index.html?itemId=/content/component/d786bb9d-en#wrapper
[3] https://www.undp.org/north-macedonia/projects/bridging-skills-gap-create-new-and-better-jobs

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 2
content.title:
PART 2 
Regional disparities in job creation

content.text:
The energy transition faces a dual challenge: regional disparities in job creation and the concentration of high-quality jobs in developed countries. While employment opportunities in the clean energy sector are growing, they are unevenly distributed across the globe. Developing a sufficiently large and skilled local workforce is imperative in every region, as most energy jobs are tied to the location where installations are developed (IEA, 2023).
China holds a widening lead in renewable energy deployment and dominates equipment manufacturing, creating a significant share of high-quality jobs. The EU and countries such as the United States, India, Brazil are also major installers, working to strengthen domestic supply chains for greater local value creation. However, this concentration of high-quality jobs in developed countries further exacerbates global inequalities, leaving many developing regions behind.
Skilled labor shortages are already evident in the clean energy sector, particularly in construction roles, which account for nearly half of new energy jobs. These shortages limit the availability of workers needed to install clean energy technologies and retrofit buildings.

Despite the growing demand, the number of workers obtaining relevant qualifications is not keeping pace. Vocational training and degrees in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) critical to the energy sector are not growing fast enough to meet this need.
Regions that rely heavily on fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, or gas, will feel the impacts of the energy transition most acutely and will require targeted support. Governments must also address the financial barriers workers face in retraining, while ensuring marginalized communities are not left behind.
A just transition requires addressing both global and regional disparities. Socioeconomic factors like income levels, education, and access to training vary widely across regions, and tailored programs are essential to build local capacities. Diversifying local job markets and prioritizing clean energy infrastructure where it’s most needed—not just where it’s easiest to implement—are crucial steps.
Ultimately, addressing these disparities and ensuring the benefits of clean energy job creation are shared more equitably is key to achieving a truly inclusive energy transition.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title:
PART 3 
Gender disparities in the energy sector

content.text:
The energy transition is an opportunity to advance gender equality and support marginalized communities. While renewable energy sectors are already more inclusive, employing 32% of women compared to 22% in the oil and gas industries, significant disparities remain, particularly in leadership roles where women occupy less than 14% of senior positions. To tap into the potential of energy transition, it must be approached with deliberate intent and supported by prioritizing gender equality in every stage of the energy transition—from policy design to workforce development.
The energy sector remains one of the least gender-diverse industries worldwide. Despite women constituting approximately 39% of the global labor force, they occupy only 16% of positions in the traditional energy sector. Moreover, women's wages in this field are nearly 15% lower than those of their male counterparts, and fewer than 15% hold senior management roles (IEA, 2024).
Addressing these disparities is crucial for fostering innovation and achieving a just energy transition. Implementing targeted interventions, such as promoting women's participation in leadership positions and ensuring equitable pay, is essential to rectify existing gender imbalances and unlock the sector's full potential.

Efforts aimed at attracting and retaining more women in the energy sector are indispensable to ensure a fair distribution of the benefits generated by the energy transition. Women are more prone than men to exit both the energy sector and the labor market altogether, underscoring the imperative of dismantling barriers hindering their participation and career progression, as revealed by data from the IEA Gender and Energy Data Explorer (2023). 
The impending shifts in labor dynamics driven by climate change carry profound gender ramifications, bearing significant policy implications. Failure to implement measures bolstering women’s engagement in emerging green vocations risks perpetuating existing gender stereotypes, thereby constricting women's access to the burgeoning job market. Hence, the adoption of "gender-transformative" reskilling initiatives spanning various proficiency levels emerges as a requisite to broaden women's pathways to novel employment prospects.

To honor the commitments outlined in the 2030 Agenda and uphold the principle of leaving no one behind, fostering inclusivity emerges as a paramount imperative. It is imperative to integrate women and girls from diverse backgrounds into the transformative journey toward sustainable energy.

While the renewable energy sphere presents fertile ground for women's progression, targeted policies and initiatives are indispensable to combat gender bias and forge environments conducive to inclusivity.

Exemplary initiatives such as Barefoot College's Solar Mamas underscore the transformative power of empowering women and nurturing their interest in STEM careers.  Increasing examples of women entrepreneurs in decentralized renewable energy (DRE) and productive uses of renewable energy (PURE) sectors offer lessons for a gender-just energy transition in rural regions. Scholarships, mentorship endeavours, capacity-building initiatives, and access to financing and other enabling conditions stand as linchpins in upskilling women and dismantling gender stereotypes prevalent within the energy sector.
Moreover, the disproportionate burden of unpaid care work borne by women  raises formidable barriers to their ingress into clean energy employment and entrepreneurship. Absent supportive policies such as flexible work arrangements or childcare provisions, women risk encountering additional hurdles in accessing clean energy avenues.  Addressing these challenges transcends mere gender equality; it is pivotal for optimizing the effectiveness and longevity of clean energy initiatives, as women's insights pave the way for more innovative and inclusive outcomes.

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

cards.title: Reskilling and Upskilling are Critical for a Just Energy Transition
cards.description: The shift from fossil fuels to renewable energy will create millions of jobs, but it also risks displacing workers in traditional energy sectors. Effective retraining programs, such as those in North Macedonia and Egypt, are essential to equip workers with the skills needed for emerging green jobs. Governments, industries, and educational institutions must collaborate to ensure these programs are inclusive, gender-sensitive, and aligned with local labor market needs.

cards.title: Regional Disparities in Job Creation Must Be Addressed
cards.description: While renewable energy job growth is global, high-quality jobs are concentrated in developed regions, exacerbating inequalities. Developing countries, especially those reliant on fossil fuels, require targeted support to build local capacities and diversify economies. Tailored policies and investments in clean energy infrastructure are crucial to ensure that the benefits of the energy transition are equitably distributed.

cards.title: Gender Equality is a Cornerstone of a Sustainable Energy Transition
cards.description: Women are underrepresented in the energy sector, particularly in leadership roles, and face barriers such as wage gaps and unpaid care work. The energy transition offers an opportunity to advance gender equality through targeted initiatives like scholarships, mentorship programs, and flexible work arrangements. Empowering women in STEM and renewable energy sectors not only promotes equity but also drives innovation and long-term sustainability.
